document_type: ISO 27001 Security Requirements - Annex A Control
applies_to_note: All gambling operators subject to RTS Chapter 4 - Security Requirements

control.control_purpose: To segregate groups of information services, users and information systems in separate networks based on security boundaries and business needs
control.control_objective: Divide networks into separate security domains to prevent lateral movement, limit access to critical systems and control information flow between network segments

iso_27001_definition.official_text: Groups of information services, users and information systems should be segregated in the organisation's networks.
key_requirements: Users segregated by role and access requirements
Information systems segregated by function and criticality
Separate networks created for different security domains
Wireless networks segregated from main networks

control_purpose_detail.purpose: Preventive control limiting lateral movement, preventing unauthorized access to critical systems and controlling information flow between network segments
control_purpose_detail.key_outcome: Network divided into security domains with controlled access between segments preventing breach from spreading across entire network

prerequisites.description: Before implementing network segmentation, foundational requirements must be met

required_prerequisites.rationale: Must understand current network to design segmentation

required_prerequisites.description: Classification of information by sensitivity level
required_prerequisites.rationale: Segmentation requirements determined by data sensitivity
Segmentation strategy aligned with identified risks
required_prerequisites.reference: ISO 27001 A 5.1 - Policies for information security

required_prerequisites.rationale: Segmentation implements and enforces access control

implementation_requirements.description: Plan network segmentation based on business needs and security risks

segmentation_planning: Identify information services to be grouped
Identify user groups by role and access needs
Identify information systems by function and criticality
Determine security boundaries and domains needed
Balance security benefits against management overhead
domain_selection_criteria: Trust levels - segregate untrusted from trusted systems
Criticality - segregate critical systems from standard systems
Function - segregate by business function or department
Data sensitivity - segregate based on data classification
Access requirements - segregate by access patterns
network_domain_types: Perimeter or DMZ domain for external access
Game systems domain for gambling operations
Payment processing domain for financial transactions
Customer data domain for personal information
Development domain for testing and development
Public or guest domain for external users
Partner or third-party domain for external connections
design_principles: Principle of least privilege - minimize inter-segment traffic
Defense in depth - multiple layers of protection
Fail-safe defaults - block unless explicitly allowed
Separation of concerns - segregate by responsibility

implementation_requirements.description: Secure the boundary between network segments and external networks

perimeter_security_elements: Firewall at network perimeter between internal and external
Access control lists enforcing segment boundaries
VPN gateways for remote and external access
perimeter_protection: Default-deny policy - only allow necessary traffic
access_control_enforcement: Firewall rules based on access control policy
Only approved traffic allowed between segments
Specific source, destination and port requirements
Protocols restricted to necessary ones only

implementation_requirements.description: Deploy VLANs and virtual network controls for segmentation

vlan_implementation: VLANs created for different network segments
Management VLAN segregated from user VLANs
virtual_network_controls: Cloud virtual networks or VPCs created for logical separation
Virtual firewall or security groups deployed
network_layer_security: Layer 3 routing enforced at segment boundaries
Quality of service (QoS) for traffic management

implementation_requirements.description: Isolate wireless networks from main network infrastructure

wireless_network_separation: Wireless networks physically or logically separated
Guest wireless network for external users
Corporate wireless network for employee access
Public wireless network for customer access
Wireless traffic isolated from wired networks
wireless_security_controls: VPN required for access to internal resources from wireless
wireless_access_restrictions: Limited functionality on public wireless networks
No critical system access from public wireless
No direct access to customer data from wireless
VPN or encryption for sensitive data from wireless

implementation_requirements.description: Establish controls for traffic flowing between network segments

inter_segment_communication: Log all inter-segment traffic for monitoring
firewall_rules: Rules define source, destination, protocol and port
Rules reviewed regularly and cleaned up
monitoring_between_segments: Correlation of segment traffic with incidents

implementation_requirements.description: Enforce access control policies across network segment boundaries

access_control_implementation: Multi-factor authentication for critical segment access
segment_specific_controls: Game systems segment - restricted to authorized personnel only
Payment segment - limited to payment processors and authorized staff
Customer data segment - restricted to staff with need-to-know
Admin segment - segregated from user access
Development segment - isolated from production systems

implementation_requirements.description: Maintain comprehensive documentation of network segmentation

segment_descriptions: Systems and services in each segment
Users and user groups accessing each segment
Data classification of information on segment

implementation_requirements.description: Establish monitoring to verify segmentation is operating effectively

alerting_and_response: Alerts for unauthorized segment access attempts

implementation_requirements.description: Conduct testing to verify network segmentation is functioning

testing_activities: Verify segment isolation from lateral movement
testing_approaches: Firewall rule testing - verify expected allow/deny behavior
Network segmentation testing - attempt unauthorized access
Configuration testing - verify configuration matches policy
Failover testing - verify backup paths work
testing_frequency: Testing as part of internal audits

steps.detail: Document existing network configuration and identify segmentation opportunities
Plan network segments based on business needs, criticality and security requirements
Document network segments, boundaries, firewall rules and access controls
Deploy VLANs and logical network segregation
Implement firewall policies enforcing segment boundaries
Isolate wireless networks from main infrastructure
Deploy authentication and authorization between segments
Deploy monitoring of inter-segment traffic and alerting
Conduct testing to verify segment isolation and access controls
Complete documentation and conduct internal audit

compliance_checklist.description: Steps to comply with ISO 27001 Annex A 8.22

checklist.item: Network segments defined by function, criticality and access requirements
Network diagrams showing all segments and boundaries created
VLANs created for each network segment
Firewall rules implemented between all segments
Wireless networks segregated from main network
Access control lists configured at segment boundaries
Inter-segment traffic monitoring and logging implemented
Network segmentation tested and verified working
Unauthorized segment access attempts detected and investigated
Regular testing of segment boundaries performed
Internal audit of network segmentation performed

common_mistakes.description: Top 3 mistakes organizations make with network segmentation

mistakes.description: All systems on same network segment allowing compromise of one system to spread across entire network
root_cause: Lack of understanding of segmentation benefits
Assumption that perimeter security is sufficient
Small network size perceived as not needing segmentation
mistakes.impact: Breach in one system exposes entire network, lateral movement enables compromise of critical systems, customer data exposure
prevention: Implement segmentation as part of network design
Segregate critical systems from general network
Use VLANs for logical segmentation if physical separation not possible
Implement firewall rules enforcing segment boundaries
Start with basic segmentation and expand as needed

mistakes.mistake: Wireless network on same security level as wired network
mistakes.description: Wireless network not segregated from main network allowing wireless compromise to affect entire network
root_cause: Wireless treated as convenience rather than security concern
Lack of understanding of wireless vulnerabilities
User expectations for full wireless access
mistakes.impact: Wireless compromise exposes network, guest access allows internal resource access, data interception
prevention: Segregate wireless networks from wired networks
Use separate VLANs for wireless and wired
Limit wireless access to non-critical resources
Require VPN for wireless access to internal resources
Implement strong wireless authentication and encryption

mistakes.mistake: Firewall rules not documented or tested
mistakes.description: Firewall rules configured but not documented or tested creating uncertainty about actual network segmentation
root_cause: No testing process for firewall rules
Rules accumulate over time without cleanup
Lack of change management for rules
mistakes.impact: Unintended access allowed, audit failures, inability to troubleshoot issues, configuration inconsistencies
prevention: Document all firewall rules with business justification
Regular review and cleanup of unused rules
Change management process for rule changes

audit_areas.description: Verify network segments are implemented and isolated

External access restricted to authorized paths

audit_areas.description: Verify wireless networks segregated from main network
checks: Wireless networks on separate VLANs or networks
Wireless access restricted to non-critical resources

audit_areas.description: Verify access controls enforced between segments

checks: Firewall rules tested and verified working

audit_areas.description: Verify critical gambling systems appropriately segregated
checks: RNG systems isolated from external networks
Admin access segregated from user access

ukgc_application.critical_systems_context: For gambling operators, network segmentation is critical for protecting game integrity, customer data and payment processing. UKGC expects network segmentation preventing breach in one system from affecting critical systems. Game servers, payment systems and customer data must be segregated with controlled access.
specific_requirements: Game servers on dedicated network segment with restricted access
Payment processing systems on segregated network segment
Customer data systems segregated from operational networks
RNG systems isolated on separate network segment
Customer account systems segregated from public-facing systems
Administrative access segregated from user networks
Wireless networks segregated from main infrastructure
External connections (payment processors, third parties) on separate segments
Firewall rules preventing unauthorized inter-segment traffic
Monitoring of segment boundaries for unauthorized access
ukgc_application.compliance_requirement: Gambling operators must implement network segmentation with segregated network segments for critical systems, documented firewall rules, and monitoring of inter-segment traffic to prevent lateral movement and protect customer data and game integrity

compliance_notes.overall_purpose: Divide networks into separate security domains to prevent lateral movement after breach and limit access to critical systems

Critical systems segregated from standard systems

gambling_operator_specific_guidance.critical_system_segregation: Game servers, payment systems and customer data systems must each be on separate network segments. RNG systems should be isolated on their own segment with restricted access. Each critical segment should have dedicated firewall rules controlling access. Access to each segment should be audited and monitored.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.payment_system_protection: Payment processing systems must be on dedicated network segment separate from game operations and customer-facing systems. Connections to external payment processors should route through dedicated path. Firewall rules should restrict payment segment access to authorized systems only. All payment segment traffic should be logged and monitored.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.customer_data_protection: Customer data systems should be on segregated network segment. Access from other segments should be restricted and authenticated. Direct user access to customer data segment should be prevented. Any inter-segment traffic involving customer data should be logged and monitored for anomalies.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.wireless_network_handling: Guest wireless should be segregated from corporate network and provide no access to internal systems or customer data. Corporate wireless should have strong authentication and encryption. Wireless traffic should be monitored for security events. Rogue access point detection should be implemented.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.audit_readiness: To be audit-ready: provide network diagrams showing segments; provide firewall rule documentation; demonstrate inter-segment traffic restrictions; provide firewall and intrusion detection logs; demonstrate monitoring of segment boundaries; show testing evidence of segment isolation; provide incident investigation records.
